post_text: Hey guyys, i've seen some people talk about this, but honestly I don't know how I feel about it. I have a PT I work with that's COMT certified and his treatment methods are very different to McKenzie methods. Ive seen posts where is has been mostly COMT PT's bashing MDT PT's but honestly I'm trying to see where they find Maitland methods to be better. A lot of the good McKenzie therapists, does not see this as "everyone does extension, they get better." They see it as a diagnostic tool. There has been several patients in my career that have been not extension responders but have been even flexion or rotational movements. We over flex as a society given that functional activities are in some form of flexion mostly. That's why I think most people respond best to extension because we over flex which cause changes in the spine/discs. For those who have had both Mckenzie training and Maitland training what do you feel is a more ideal method to diagnose and treat patients? Also, do you find one method or the other to be better for different pathologies?
comments_text: No one should be bashing any one style. The reality is, they all help for the right patients. Some patients will respond better to Maitland, others to Mckenzie, others to [insert other style]. Your job as a PT is to have as many tools in the toolbox as possible so that when you come across a patient, you can not only fit them into the right style but the right technique in that style. Not everyone is a Mckenzie patient. And that's ok. I do a lot of counterstrain- and not everyone is a counterstrain patient, and that's ok.

I‚Äôm Maitland certified and I think it‚Äôs appalling that any PT is bashing another technique. I think the best PTs are the ones with lots of varying tools available to them. At its core, Maitland is an assessment approach (not a treatment technique). The accessory mobility assessment does often lead to treatment (ie. Mobilizations) but in actuality I find the treatment often aligns with preferential directional treatment (which I believe falls under the McKenzie theories). I‚Äôm not McKenzie trained, but I have worked with McKenzie therapists‚Ä¶ and I think the two approaches actually blend quite well together.

In order to officially offer PWR, LSVT BIG, or Rock Steady, you would need to take the respective courses to get certified. To offer PWR as a non-therapist, you could get certified as an instructor. That track is geared toward the various fitness instructor roles, and can of course also be taken by clinicians. Rock Steady is by default a wellness/exercise based certification. You can get certified as a therapist and could use the ideas in your practice, but you would not be providing the skills of your discipline. It would be a Rock Steady class. As far as I know, there are only clinician certifications for LSVT BIG. There is BIG for Life, though, which may be something other fitness instructors qualify to get certified in. I frankly haven't seen many of those classes, and there's a prerequisite for the patient/client to have already gone through and graduated from a full round of LSVT BIG. ... I am certified in both PWR and LSVT BIG as a clinician. I have a mobile therapy model and rarely use LSVT BIG because it's exhausting to me personally, and because most of my clients would struggle with the intensity due to age, anxiety, orthopedic concerns, etc. I plan to get certified as a PWR Moves Instructor, which is way more focused on building an exercise class. As a therapist, I highly value both PWR certification tracks. (I might also get a personal training cert.) Keep in mind that if you do mobile THERAPY visits, most of these folks have Medicare or a Medicare replacement plan with out of network benefits.
